infodynamics.measures.discrete

Class MutualInformationCalculatorDiscrete

  • java.lang.Object
    • infodynamics.measures.discrete.InfoMeasureCalculatorDiscrete
      • infodynamics.measures.discrete.MutualInformationCalculatorDiscrete
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    ChannelCalculatorDiscrete, AnalyticNullDistributionComputer

    public class MutualInformationCalculatorDiscrete
extends InfoMeasureCalculatorDiscrete
implements ChannelCalculatorDiscrete, AnalyticNullDistributionComputer

    Mutual information (MI) calculator for univariate discrete (int[]) data.

    Usage of the class is intended to follow this paradigm:

    1. Construct the calculator: MutualInformationCalculatorDiscrete(int) or MutualInformationCalculatorDiscrete(int, int);
    2. Initialise the calculator using initialise();
    3. Provide the observations/samples for the calculator to set up the PDFs, using one or more calls to sets of addObservations(int[], int[]) methods, then
    4. Compute the required quantities, being one or more of:
      • the average MI: computeAverageLocalOfObservations();
      • local MI values, such as computeLocalFromPreviousObservations(int[], int[]);
      • comparison to null distribution, such as computeSignificance();
      • and variants of these.
    5. As an alternative to steps 3 and 4, the user may undertake standalone computation from a single set of observations, via e.g.: computeLocal(int[][], int, int).
    6. Return to step 2 to re-use the calculator on a new data set.

    References:

    • T. M. Cover and J. A. Thomas, 'Elements of Information Theory' (John Wiley & Sons, New York, 1991).
    Author:
    Joseph Lizier (email, www)

      • addObservations

        public void addObservations(int[] var1,
                   int[] var2)

        Adds a new set of observations to update the PDFs with. It is intended to be called multiple times.

        Important: this does not append these observations to the previously supplied observations, but treats them independently - i.e. measurements such as the transfer entropy will not join them up to examine k consecutive values in time.

        Pairs for MI are between the arrays var1 and var2, separated in time by timeDiff (var1 is first).
        Specified by:
        addObservations in interface ChannelCalculatorDiscrete
        Parameters:
        var1 - series of observations for the source variable.

      • addObservations

        public void addObservations(int[][] states,
                   int iCol,
                   int jCol)

        Adds a new set of observations to update the PDFs with, from within a multivariate time-series. It is intended to be called multiple times.

        Important: this does not append these observations to the previously supplied observations, but treats them independently - i.e. measurements such as the transfer entropy will not join them up to examine k consecutive values in time.

        Pairs for MI are between columns iCol and jCol, separated in time by timeDiff (i is first).
        Specified by:
        addObservations in interface ChannelCalculatorDiscrete
        Parameters:
        states - 2D multivariate time series (first index is time second indexes the variable)
        iCol - column index for the source variable.
        jCol - column index for the destination variable.

      • computeSignificance

        public EmpiricalMeasurementDistribution computeSignificance(int numPermutationsToCheck)
        Description copied from interface: ChannelCalculatorDiscrete
        Generate a bootstrapped distribution of what the channel measure would look like, under a null hypothesis that the source values of our samples had no relation to the destination value. (Precise null hypothesis varies between MI and TE).

        See Section II.E "Statistical significance testing" of the JIDT paper below for a description of how this is done for MI, conditional MI and TE.

        Note that if several disjoint time-series have been added as observations using ChannelCalculatorDiscrete.addObservations(int[], int[]) etc., then these separate "trials" will be mixed up in the generation of surrogates here.

        Specified by:
        computeSignificance in interface ChannelCalculatorDiscrete
        Parameters:
        numPermutationsToCheck - number of surrogate samples to bootstrap to generate the distribution.
        Returns:
        the distribution of channel measure scores under this null hypothesis.
        See Also:
        "J.T. Lizier, 'JIDT: An information-theoretic toolkit for studying the dynamics of complex systems', 2014."

      • computeSignificance

        public EmpiricalMeasurementDistribution computeSignificance(int[][] newOrderings)
        Generate a bootstrapped distribution of what the MI would look like, under a null hypothesis that the source values of our samples had no relation to the destination values.

        See Section II.E "Statistical significance testing" of the JIDT paper below for a description of how this is done for a mutual information. Basically, the marginal PDFs of each marginal are preserved, while their joint PDF is destroyed, and the distribution of MI under these conditions is generated.

        Note that if several disjoint time-series have been added as observations using #addObservations(double[]) etc., then these separate "trials" will be mixed up in the generation of surrogates here.

        This method (in contrast to computeSignificance(int)) allows the user to specify how to construct the surrogates, such that repeatable results may be obtained.

        Parameters:
        newOrderings - a specification of how to shuffle the next values to create the surrogates to generate the distribution with. The first index is the permutation number (i.e. newOrderings.length is the number of surrogate samples we use to bootstrap to generate the distribution here.) Each array newOrderings[i] should be an array of length N (where would be the value returned by InfoMeasureCalculatorDiscrete.getNumObservations()), containing a permutation of the values in 0..(N-1).
        Returns:
        the distribution of MI scores under this null hypothesis.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - where the length of each permutation in newOrderings is not equal to the number N samples that were previously supplied.
        See Also:
        "J.T. Lizier, 'JIDT: An information-theoretic toolkit for studying the dynamics of complex systems', 2014."

      • computeSignificance

        public AnalyticMeasurementDistribution computeSignificance()
        Description copied from interface: AnalyticNullDistributionComputer
        Generate an analytic distribution of what a given measure would look like, under a null hypothesis that the source values of our samples had no relation to the destination value (possibly in the context of a conditional value).

        See Section II.E "Statistical significance testing" of the JIDT paper below for a description of how this is done for MI, conditional MI and TE as per the references below.

        References:

        • J.T. Lizier, "JIDT: An information-theoretic toolkit for studying the dynamics of complex systems", 2014.
        • Brillinger, "Some data analyses using mutual information", Brazilian Journal of Probability and Statistics, 18, p. 163, (2004)
        • Cheng et al., "Data Information in Contingency Tables: A Fallacy of Hierarchical Loglinear Models", Journal of Data Science, 4, p. 387 (2006).
        • Geweke, "Measurement of Linear Dependence and Feedback between Multiple Time Series", Journal of the American Statistical Association, 77, p. 304-313 (1982).
        • Barnett and Bossomaier, "Transfer Entropy as a Log-likelihood Ratio", Physical Review Letters, 109, p. 138105+ (2012).
        Specified by:
        computeSignificance in interface AnalyticNullDistributionComputer
        Returns:
        the analytic distribution of channel measure scores under this null hypothesis.

      • computeLocalFromPreviousObservations

        public double computeLocalFromPreviousObservations(int val1,
                                          int val2)
                                            throws java.lang.Exception
        Computes local mutual information (or pointwise mutual information) for the given (single) specific values, using pdfs built up from observations previously sent in via the addObservations method.
        Parameters:
        val1 - single specific value of variable 1
        val2 - single specific value of variable 2
        Returns:
        a local mutual information value for this pair of observations
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - if this pair were not observed together in the previously supplied observations

      • computeLocalFromPreviousObservations

        public double[] computeLocalFromPreviousObservations(int[] var1,
                                            int[] var2)
                                              throws java.lang.Exception
        Computes local mutual information (or pointwise mutual information) for the given states, using pdfs built up from observations previously sent in via the addObservations method
        Parameters:
        var1 - new states of variable 1
        var2 - new states of variable 2. Should be same length as var1
        Returns:
        array of local mutual information values for each observation of (var1, var2). Note - if timeDiff > 0, then the return length will be var1.length - timeDiff.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • computeLocalFromPreviousObservations

        public double[] computeLocalFromPreviousObservations(int[][] states,
                                            int iCol,
                                            int jCol)
        Computes local mutual information (or pointwise mutual information) for the given states, using pdfs built up from observations previously sent in via the addObservations method
        Parameters:
        states - 2D time series of observations (first index time, second is variable index)
        iCol - column number for first variable
        jCol - column number for second variable
        Returns:
        array of local mutual information values for each observation of (var1, var2). Note - if timeDiff > 0, then the return length will be var1.length - timeDiff.

      • computeLocal

        public double[] computeLocal(int[][] states,
                    int iCol,
                    int jCol)
        Standalone routine to compute local mutual information (or pointwise mutual information) across a 2D spatiotemporal array of the states of homogeneous agents Return a 2D spatiotemporal array of local values. First history rows are zeros
        Parameters:
        states - 2D time series of observations (first index time, second is variable index)
        iCol - column number for first variable
        jCol - column number for second variable
        Returns:
        array of local mutual information values for each observation of (var1, var2). Note - if timeDiff > 0, then the return length will be var1.length - timeDiff.
